DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the extent of improvement in a person following surgical resection of disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery._In medicine, an improvement related to treatment._Post; occuring after._Removal or excision by surgical measures.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.:In medicine, an improvement related to treatment.

Concepts.definition: of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.

Property.preferredDefinition: Post; occuring after.:Removal or excision by surgical measures.

Concepts.definition: Happening at a time subsequent to a reference time; later in time or order.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results or effects (does not include CTC Adverse Events) of therapeutic agents or procedures administered to the patient.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery._In medicine, an improvement related to treatment._Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Unable to be removed with surgery.

Concepts.definition: Not capable of being removed by surgery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving advantage or good.: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Negative; involving disadvantage or harm.: The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results or effects (does not include CTC Adverse Events) of therapeutic agents or procedures administered to the patient.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.:In medicine, an improvement related to treatment.:Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.
The pathologic and/or clinical changes that result from treatment. The changes may include eradication of detectable disease, stabilization of disease, or disease progression.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
